description: An 89-year-old woman in central New York was found dead in the snow outside her home during this week's winter storm Stella. A snowplow worker was shoveling snow when he found her body.
title: Snow plow worker finds 89-year-old woman dead in the snow
title_page: Snow plow worker finds 89-year-old woman dead in the snow | Daily Mail Online
text:
An 89-year-old woman in central New York was found dead in the snow outside her home during this week's winter storm Stella.
Police said a private snowplow contractor was shoveling around 10.45am Tuesday at the woman's home in Otisco, 10 miles south of Syracuse.
The contractors found her body by her front door.
Investigators said the woman likely slipped and fell or suffered a medical emergency as she walked outside.
An 89-year-old woman in central New York was found dead in the snow outside her home during this week's winter storm Stella. Police said a private snowplow contractor (file) was shoveling around 10.45am Tuesday at the woman's home in Otisco
Authorities say it's not known how long she had been outside. Police haven't released the woman's name.
The Onondaga County Medical Examiner's Office will perform an autopsy to determine the woman's cause of death.
Her death was not the only one reported after storm Stella hit the northeast this week.
A 10-year-old boy died after being trapped under a pile of snow in Niagara County on Wednesday afternoon.
He was pronounced dead at a hospital. Authorities believe the young boy was digging a tunnel when it collapsed on him.
On Wednesday, two other deaths in New York were reported.
On Wednesday, two other deaths in New York were reported. A 47-year-old man in Staten Island and a 38-year-old man in Walkill, died of apparent heart attacks as they tried to clear snow outside their homes (file image)
A 47-year-old man in Staten Island and a 38-year-old man in Walkill, died of apparent heart attacks as they tried to clear snow outside their homes, according to NBC New York.
Storm Stella dumped more than two feet of snow on parts of the Syracuse area and Niagara County.
Officials warned 50 million people on Monday to prepare for the would-be crippling effects of a blizzard.
More than 4,000 flights were canceled in anticipation of winter storm Stella.
